hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: Prayer is valid behind every righteous and sinful person, and pray over every righteous and sinful person.

chainIssues: Jarah ibn al-Dahhak is majhul al-hal at the beginning of the chain
Asim ibn Rajaa ibn Hayawah is classified as da'if (weak)
Multiple 'an (عَنِ) transmissions without explicit hearing terms except for the first narrator
The chain structure appears to include both sequential narrators and may have missing or incomplete transmission information

potential_issues.issue: Jarah ibn al-Dahhak ibn Qays is majhul al-hal (unknown condition) at the beginning of the chain
potential_issues.impact: Having an unknown narrator at the beginning weakens the overall reliability of the isnad. His reliability status is not established.

potential_issues.issue: Asim ibn Rajaa ibn Hayawah is classified as da'if (weak)
potential_issues.impact: The presence of a weak narrator in the chain significantly compromises the hadith's authenticity. This is a substantial defect.

potential_issues.issue: Combination of majhul and da'if narrators in the same chain
potential_issues.impact: Having both an unknown narrator (majhul) and a weak narrator (da'if) in the same chain creates compounded reliability issues.

Topics: Validity of prayer behind pious and sinful leaders
Prayer validity regardless of leader's moral character
Prayer over deceased righteous and sinful individuals
Islamic ruling on prayer conduct in various circumstances

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Umar: Obey the Imam even if he strikes you, deprives you, or wrongs you. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ commanded obedience to the emir (leader) even if he was sinful, and ordered prayer over him when he died. How then should it be with others from the people of the Qibla who affirm Allah, His angels, His books, His messengers, and the Last Day? Whoever says otherwise has disbelieved with disbelief short of polytheism.

narrators.name: Umar ibn al-Khattab
narrators.full_name: Umar ibn al-Khattab ibn al-Nassa ibn Kilab

chainIssues: This is a mawquf statement, stopped at a companion (Umar) rather than attributed to the Prophet ﷺ
The chain is very short, consisting of only two narrators separated by generations
Abdullah ibn Nafi appears to be the sole transmitter from Umar for this statement

potential_issues.issue: This is mawquf (stopped at companion level), not marfu' to the Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: The statement is attributed to Umar (a companion) rather than directly to the Prophet ﷺ, which affects its authority and classification. It should not be considered a prophetic hadith but rather a companion's statement.

potential_issues.issue: Very short chain with significant gap between narrator and Umar
potential_issues.impact: Abdullah ibn Nafi is reported as narrating directly from Umar without intermediaries, but this is unusual and may indicate a potential disconnection or missing narrators.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Obligation to obey the leader even if unjust
Endurance of leadership tyranny and injustice
Prayer over deceased leaders regardless of their righteousness

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ali ibn Abi Talib: When he sent messengers to Mu'awiyah ibn Abi Sufyan, he said: Pray in your dwellings and make your prayer with them a custom, for Allah accepts only from the pious. Hassan al-Basri and Sa'id ibn Jubayr used to pray Jumu'ah in their houses and then go out to the mosque to pray with the governor of Banu Umayyah, and they would make their prayer with him a custom.

narrators.full_name: Ali ibn Abi Talib ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: This is a mawquf statement, stopped at a companion (Ali ibn Abi Talib) rather than attributed to the Prophet ﷺ
The chain is very short with only one transmitter (Abdullah ibn Ubaid) between the collector and the companion
The text includes commentary about Hassan al-Basri and Sa'id ibn Jubayr's practices rather than direct narration

potential_issues.issue: This is mawquf (stopped at companion level), not marfu' to the Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: The statement is attributed to Ali ibn Abi Talib (a companion) rather than to the Prophet ﷺ. This reduces its authority as a prophetic tradition.

potential_issues.issue: The hadith contains narrative commentary mixing Ali's statement with later scholars' practices
potential_issues.impact: The content blends Ali's statement with historical accounts of Hassan al-Basri and Sa'id ibn Jubayr's actions, making it a compound transmission with mixed sources.

potential_issues.issue: Single transmitter (Abdullah ibn Ubaid) from the companion level
potential_issues.impact: Having only one narrator from Ali creates a potential issue of isolation, and the reliability of this single transmitter becomes crucial.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Ubaydah: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Do not let fear of people prevent any of you from speaking the truth when you witness it, and from rejecting falsehood when you are able to do so.

narrators.name: Muhammad ibn Yusuf ibn Hikam
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Yusuf ibn Hikam al-Hadani

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: The hadith is introduced with 'ballaghani' (بَلَغَنِي عَنْ رَسُولِ اللَّهِ) which is the weakest transmission term
Direct attribution from Muhammad ibn Yusuf to the Prophet ﷺ without any intermediate narrators or companions
Missing chain between late 8th century narrator and 7th century Prophet

potential_issues.issue: Use of 'ballaghani' (بَلَغَنِي) - the weakest transmission method
potential_issues.impact: Ballaghani indicates the report merely reached the narrator through unspecified means without a clear, documented chain. This is one of the most severe defects in hadith transmission.

potential_issues.issue: Apparent chain disconnection between 8th century narrator and 7th century Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'ballaghani' with no intermediate narrators creates a clear gap (munqati') in the chain, making this essentially a mursal hadith.

potential_issues.issue: No companion or generation-bridge narrators in the visible chain
potential_issues.impact: The chain jumps from Muhammad ibn Yusuf directly to the Prophet ﷺ, which is chronologically impossible and indicates missing crucial transmission links.

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Overcoming fear of people in religious matters
Courage in enjoining right and forbidding wrong
